Personally i quit the effort and moved to my Windows machine in order to have a nice and tidy start.

results.content: This is the in-depth look into the PHP structure within Wordpress that I have been waiting years for. Because Wordpress is mostly aimed at designers rather than coders, most Wordpress training, and even textbooks, are painfully simplistic, barely touching on the nature of the Wordpress PHP and database back end, if at all. Not the case, here. I was blown away that within the first few lessons, we're already creating a new theme from scratch, from blank pages, using pure PHP and CSS.  It covers the exact structure of Wordpress, learning PHP from scratch, literally leaves nothing out. Which is perfect for a front end web designer who would like to uncover the layers of Wordpress and the ever mysterious back end. For that matter, you don't even really need any deep front end knowledge to get started here. This course is worth buying even at full price. Thank you for tackling this subject, and doing it so thoroughly!

results.content:
The speed at which this course progresses is perfect for the topics it covers.  I'm new to WordPress theme development, and I'm very thankful that Brad takes the time to slow down and explain what each function does and why you should use it.

All the other theme development courses I've enrolled in have breezed through integrating PHP into static HTML, leaving almost no leeway for people who are new to the subject to catch up, and, worst of all, don't cover why you'd need a particular line of code in order to reach the final product.

Brad does both these things while seamlessly teaching new material at the same time, and because of his teaching style and efforts to clarify the material he teaches, I'm able to feel more confident with this topic and eventually apply it into my own work outside of Udemy.

Thank you so much for creating this course!  I may only be on the 15th lecture, but I really do admire the way you've decided to present this knowledge and share it with others.  I can't wait to work through the rest of this course and use what it's taught me in my own projects.

results.content:
Reached Section 10, Lecture 41 (review will be updated): 
This course is amazing in every aspect of course there are some stuff that are missing  but hey no course is complete. 
You should know that Brad explanation is great, I know him from YouTube and I am a 1000% sure that I will learn a lot from this course no doubt. Overall good so far...
Annoying things:
-------------------------
Brad states clearly states that this is a WordPress, PHP and few JS course. Not CSS nor HTML BUT sometimes WordPress itself injects CSS that into your static site that he does not talk about while he should (he is not teaching CSS, but WordPress now, this teaches students what WordPress injects  in the case of body_class( ) per example 

 How did he fix the annoying navbar of WordPress hiding your web site navbar - suddenly in a video it was fixed without telling the reason or how - it bothered me a lot like in the beginning so I gave a  low rank (I know how from another course (there is a CSS Wordpress class called .logged-in that needs to be addressed on different media queries) but this is not explained while other non important things are explained in great details.

Also the method of invoking your js files and CSS files in php-functions is terrible and  is not complete. I try to used it in a live project and it pissed everybody at work, it caused all sorts of problems (Brad you did not talk about Dependencies like when you load Bootstrap it depends on JQuery and how you can set that. if i followed some guides it did not work so i throwed it in the garbage
results.content_html:
Reached Section 10, Lecture 41 (review will be updated):
This course is amazing in every aspect of course there are some stuff that are missing but hey no course is complete.
You should know that Brad explanation is great, I know him from YouTube and I am a 1000% sure that I will learn a lot from this course no doubt. Overall good so far...
Annoying things:
-------------------------
Brad states clearly states that this is a WordPress, PHP and few JS course. Not CSS nor HTML BUT sometimes WordPress itself injects CSS that into your static site that he does not talk about while he should (he is not teaching CSS, but WordPress now, this teaches students what WordPress injects in the case of body_class( ) per example

How did he fix the annoying navbar of WordPress hiding your web site navbar - suddenly in a video it was fixed without telling the reason or how - it bothered me a lot like in the beginning so I gave a low rank (I know how from another course (there is a CSS Wordpress class called .logged-in that needs to be addressed on different media queries) but this is not explained while other non important things are explained in great details.

Also the method of invoking your js files and CSS files in php-functions is terrible and is not complete. I try to used it in a live project and it pissed everybody at work, it caused all sorts of problems (Brad you did not talk about Dependencies like when you load Bootstrap it depends on JQuery and how you can set that. if i followed some guides it did not work so i throwed it in the garbage

results.content:
On the surface, this course sounds great. I signed up due that the course covers a lot of information on theme development, custom post types, custom fields. Keep in mind, if you're interested in developing these from scratch without the use of a  plugin such as Advanced Custom Fields (ACF), you may want to keep looking. 

The instructor does cover the material in a real-world project. However, if you're a veteran developer like I am and just want the "meat and potatoes"  of the content, this course may not be for you.  I found the content delivery was a bit slow and on the "elementary" side. I felt like I was 2 years old and back in grade school.

Strongly recommend this course.

results.content:
One of the best WordPress theme dev (and more) courses out there right now.  Brad takes a very methodical approach to moving you through WordPress theme development, so that you're able to learn a piece at a time.  The information is taught at a very reasonable pace, and never presented in an overwhelming manner.

Brad keeps this course updated often, so you continue to get more out of it ... he published the course many months prior to the release of the Gutenberg editor and has now updated the course with explanations of not only what it's about, but how to make your own custom blocks ... so the course literally just keeps getting better.

I'm making another run through the course to smooth over some edges of my learning and hit the new stuff he's put out there over the last few months, and I'm loving it. Brad is a great instructor, and he makes the course fun and interesting.

I'm not sure I've ever had this much fun taking a course, so with all that I've said above, I'd highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to grow their WP theme dev skills.  Thanks for a great course, Brad!
results.content_html:

I'm not sure I've ever had this much fun taking a course, so with all that I've said above, I'd highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to grow their WP theme dev skills. Thanks for a great course, Brad!

results.content: This course truly is amazing. The instructor is articulate and thorough. The entire "fictional university" theme and its related frontend project provide a complete perspective on how dynamic frontend apps interact with the powerful and secure Wordpress backend. Some students may find him covering subjects too quickly, but one only needs to pause the video and rewind complex parts if necessary — a process I find much more enjoyable for a 25 hour course rather than increasing course length by having the instructor slow down his presentation.

results.content: Revisited after a while because I hadn't completed the course when I first purchased. It seems that the instructor is not maintaining this course anymore. I am disappointed because I always got so much out of his courses, and this course was really unique (and still would be if maintained). I would say that as this course stands right now it is great for people like myself who are not beginners as some things can be confusing for those that are just starting out. Even for us that have been coding for a while, it can be. But if you persevere, check the code that is being shared in resources, check what others are sharing in the individual videos, you will end up learning a lot and will be successful in completing this course. There are, however, things that could have/should have been added to this course, like git from the get-go, which then would mean going over how to secure sensitive data in wp-config.php for example, and API keys (just making a git repo private no longer cuts it if one wants to do professional WordPress development), so how to use environment variables, etc. Even given its current shortcomings,  I still do strongly recommend this course.

results.content:
Good course. Now it could dispense with jQuery since javascript DOM api can do pretty much the same (with a bit more code, admittedly), but I'd say that in a course, using vanilla javascript would be preferable.

The only complaint I have is that the coding style of the teacher is not as clean and consistent as it could be.

Also, I dislike using "classes" in javascript, but that's more a personal taste. Javascript doesn't really have classes, you can do exactly the same but easier with just functions (and indeed you're already doing it under the hood even if you use the class syntax).

You don't want to deal with "prototypes" if you can avoid it...
results.content_html:

results.content:
Very thorough. When I found mistakes, then it had either been addressed in the Q&A (i.e. ".dev" issue), or I needed to rewatch the videos more carefully. (I'm watching and following along at fastest speed)

I'm also really appreciative that the video editing expects the user to pause so there's no idle time. One of my pet peeves when watching instructional videos is to have the video editor person consistently waste block seconds of my time because their computer isn't as fast as mine is. I'm perfectly happy pausing and rewinding if I missed something.

Other things:
1) interesting to listen to. (no mono-tone).
2) useful for myself already being a very capable programmer
3) gives good explanation for what upcoming lessons are about or instructions for where to skip to if we're not interested in certain parts (e.g. windows vs mac so I don't need to watch both, or 'the next lesson is on ___')
4) examples are very specific and to the point ... I for myself don't need to see the examples, but I have experience seeing others teach these same principles, and this guy does it much better than most. (i.e. explaining what a variable is, how and why we use functions, etc)

I'm very happy with this course and recommend it to all. This course truly fulfills it's title to become a wordpress developer using php. (Note: I haven't gone through it all yet)
results.content_html:
Very thorough. When I found mistakes, then it had either been addressed in the Q&A (i.e. ".dev" issue), or I needed to rewatch the videos more carefully. (I'm watching and following along at fastest speed)

I'm also really appreciative that the video editing expects the user to pause so there's no idle time. One of my pet peeves when watching instructional videos is to have the video editor person consistently waste block seconds of my time because their computer isn't as fast as mine is. I'm perfectly happy pausing and rewinding if I missed something.

Other things:
1) interesting to listen to. (no mono-tone).
2) useful for myself already being a very capable programmer
3) gives good explanation for what upcoming lessons are about or instructions for where to skip to if we're not interested in certain parts (e.g. windows vs mac so I don't need to watch both, or 'the next lesson is on ___')
4) examples are very specific and to the point ... I for myself don't need to see the examples, but I have experience seeing others teach these same principles, and this guy does it much better than most. (i.e. explaining what a variable is, how and why we use functions, etc)

I'm very happy with this course and recommend it to all. This course truly fulfills it's title to become a wordpress developer using php. (Note: I haven't gone through it all yet)

results.content: This is by far, the most easy-to-understand course I have encountered on Udemy, or anywhere on line, in my experience.  The instructor's style of explaining things using clear & relatable analogies, makes understanding technical concepts easy.  Additionally, the instructor speaks at a pace that's easy to follow.  Perhaps best of all, he does not assume new learners (beginners) already know specific terminology or technical tools, henceforth, he defines technical terms first, prior to delving into the subject matter.  This is crucial for any course on coding.  For anyone who considers himself or herself a beginner in this topic, or perhaps even someone intermediate, I highly recommend this course!

results.content:
Though I have not reached the half-way point in the course, I am feeling like this is the richest online course I have taken. I like the instructor's style and tone. Very encouraging. 

The course material is not for the faint-of-heart. Though I have experience in several programming languages, PHP is not one of them. It seems like people who have some PHP experience would find this easier. Yet the instructor is a "let's keep things moving" kind of guy which has kept me from getting bogged down. The finished code is provided at the end of each lesson, so if we get miserably stuck and cannot find our error, we can just copy the "final" text and move on with the next lesson. I confess that I resorted to that twice. Without that safety valve I may have given up.

非常仔細的教學，尤其是特別開一堂課教安裝及設定「Virtulbox&Vagrant」，感恩！！

我的Wacom平板電腦系統中因為沒有VT-X/AMD-x，所以無法安裝「Local by Flywheel」。我花了一整晚爬文找影片都沒有找到解決問題的方法，最後只好嘗試看看安裝「Virtulbox&Vagrant」,竟然裝成功了！！

但是我又要重新爬文找影片來學如何設定「Virtulbox&Vagrant」,後來想說還是先將這堂課聽完再繼續爬文，沒想到講師竟然已經安排好了下堂課專門來教安裝及設定「Virtulbox&Vagrant」，真是非常感謝！！

results.content:
This course should be taught respecting WordPress coding standards and industry standards, but on several occasions so far, this has been ignored.  Teaching bad habits and standards contrary to accepted standards does damage to the reputation of the course and the reputation of the student.  Opting to hard code menus rather than leverage available WordPress admin functionality further compounds the number of bad habits being taught.

Critically, opportunities to teach good development ethos and approaches are deliberately avoided with large amounts of code repetition, mixing "view" and "logic" in front-end development and, amazingly, skipping the opportunity to teach module development by simply suggesting downloaded plugins.  Workflow tools are introduced, then glossed over without even adequate explanation.  The course is poorly presented, erratic and incomplete.

The instructor also seems very reluctant to get involved in feedback on Q&A's and has not updated git-hub provided resources that have errors in them (the gulpfile, as it stands, is destined to get stuck awaiting a promise completion and could be fixed with a few quick edits).

This course really will not help anyone become a rounded, competent WordPress developer.  Skip it and look for something else.
results.content_html:
This course should be taught respecting WordPress coding standards and industry standards, but on several occasions so far, this has been ignored. Teaching bad habits and standards contrary to accepted standards does damage to the reputation of the course and the reputation of the student. Opting to hard code menus rather than leverage available WordPress admin functionality further compounds the number of bad habits being taught.

Critically, opportunities to teach good development ethos and approaches are deliberately avoided with large amounts of code repetition, mixing "view" and "logic" in front-end development and, amazingly, skipping the opportunity to teach module development by simply suggesting downloaded plugins. Workflow tools are introduced, then glossed over without even adequate explanation. The course is poorly presented, erratic and incomplete.

The instructor also seems very reluctant to get involved in feedback on Q&A's and has not updated git-hub provided resources that have errors in them (the gulpfile, as it stands, is destined to get stuck awaiting a promise completion and could be fixed with a few quick edits).

This course really will not help anyone become a rounded, competent WordPress developer. Skip it and look for something else.

results.content:
Finally I am learning the core concepts of WordPress development instead of best designing practices. Not that it isn't covered, but this is about coding and developing to build a site from scratch and the course I've been in search of all along.   

Out of all the WordPress Development courses I have tried, even one that I really enjoy. Brad is the best instructor I've taken lessons with. He takes great deal of time extensively breaking down the core concepts and why they are being incorporated before even getting close to the bigger project.

Also, Rather than focusing on diving into the css files to start defining the base design and best practices, he instead focuses on WordPress functionality. Again, those are going to come into play but designing isn't what I needed to learn. For the future theme project I am going to build; I needed to learn the codex, Brad does that. From what I can see, he is going to take us through each step of building the theme file structure before we start any css design and layout. I can tell that by the time I'm done with this course. I'll finally have the understanding I needed to custom develop. Evcen what I've learned already, I could do more than I ever had in the past in order to add the functionality  I needed.

If you wanted to ever get away from the typical tuts teaching css and actual php WP codex. You'll want this course. I couldn't be more happy with his teaching style.

results.content: It is indeed a good match for me. However, Brad really needs to teach students on "HOW TO FIND IN GOOGLE/WORDPRESS.ORG", etc the WP functions that he keeps referring to. Students need to learn how to read documentation in the sites, so that they can create their own projects using their own BRAINS as well. Example is wp_insert_posts_data. He says that this function takes two parameters, both of them array, but only the second parameter contains the post ID, not the first one. How is a student supposed to remember all this, if he doesn't get the hang of going through word press documentation. Not all syntax will match. Students will be left over ONLY with the project in this course. It will be difficult for them to create their own.

results.content: Lots of material covered, but also a lot of cutting and pasting in code that the instructor previously wrote. You can tell things are a couple years old because many sections had to have caveats added. Numerous sections DO NOT WORK with the original filming from 2017. This causes lots of problems because subsequent lessons depend on certain things being in place. So much extra time spent spinning my wheels trying to make things work.  Examples: (1) Workflow. First time we hear the word 'vagrant'. All of the setup work from the beginning of the course is gone and suddenly we're introduced to vagrant and vamp. Oh by the way, in order to get workflow working, you have to delete the stuff you originally downloaded and load new code.  (2) Google maps. Wow! What a cluster. I get that google added the part where you are required to have a credit card on file. But this entire section should be re-recorded to be accurate for those who bother to get the api key. Why? Because at no point does Brad go into enabling Places API. And you're dead in the water for the rest of maps and campuses if you don't do that. I still have a white box where the interactive map should be. No errors when recompiling the java code. The class has gone from 'fun' and 'informative' to just plain frustrating because so much time and effort is required to move from one step to the next
results.content_html: Lots of material covered, but also a lot of cutting and pasting in code that the instructor previously wrote. You can tell things are a couple years old because many sections had to have caveats added. Numerous sections DO NOT WORK with the original filming from 2017. This causes lots of problems because subsequent lessons depend on certain things being in place. So much extra time spent spinning my wheels trying to make things work. Examples: (1) Workflow. First time we hear the word 'vagrant'. All of the setup work from the beginning of the course is gone and suddenly we're introduced to vagrant and vamp. Oh by the way, in order to get workflow working, you have to delete the stuff you originally downloaded and load new code. (2) Google maps. Wow! What a cluster. I get that google added the part where you are required to have a credit card on file. But this entire section should be re-recorded to be accurate for those who bother to get the api key. Why? Because at no point does Brad go into enabling Places API. And you're dead in the water for the rest of maps and campuses if you don't do that. I still have a white box where the interactive map should be. No errors when recompiling the java code. The class has gone from 'fun' and 'informative' to just plain frustrating because so much time and effort is required to move from one step to the next

Hi, I could not run Local by Flywheel so I went with MAMP as instructed. But from that point there are not instructions on how to continue. I can't even start the fictional university. I searched through all the folders and can't find one that looks like the folder mentioned in the course. I also searched through the questions to see if others have had the same issue and a lot of questions don't have responses. 

I would like to know if I could just do this on a regular online wordpress site? one that I would keep private and use it just for practice. Do we have to work locally?? I'm trying to find a workaround and any instructions on what to do if you can't use Flywheel and it is extremely frustrating. I bought this course because I was frustrated about being stumped on some things for a site I am working on. Now I'm stumped again. Ugh.

results.content:
TLDR: This is a quality course created by a quality instructor. 

I feel very comfortable saying that I would highly recommend this course if you want to learn WordPress and how to create your own custom themes.

Out of all the courses I have taken on Udemy, this is the first course where I feel like I'm not just copying verbatim what the instructor is typing. This feels like an actual coding boot camp type of class (without the quizzes and the personal projects). The course wasn't put together just so that the instructor could make a few bucks. Brad put a lot of thought into this course, how it's structured, how it's organized, and how it is delivered.

I also found that can work good as a reference cause he is showing step by step. I hope he will make more WP Development courses with more intermediate to advanced content. Like advanced filtering and sorting i.e. using FacetWP or Isotope.js, jQuery sortable with linked columns, multistep pages etc
Highly recommended!

results.content:
FINALLY!  I had the time to invest to sit-down and go through the course, step-by-step.  I gave myself the goal of knocking-down a section of the course per day.

The course is well-detailed and gave me a great perspective on how to develop Web sites using WordPress as their platform.  It helped dispel, and clarify, and shed light into many unknowns and unclear issues which I had, up until that point.

The instructor is meticulous to let one know about pitfalls, how to best avoid them and, whenever available, how to make sure not to run into similar pitfalls in the future.

I had worked with WordPress in the past, prior to taking this course.  However, it was in a highly demanding environment, and under the worst of conditions.  I really did not have the opportunity to sit-down and learn to develop PHP code for WordPress.  There was just a blind demand for results from someone who was a PHP developer but certainly knew nothing about WordPress development.

Again, the course is PERFECT!  I strongly recommend it to anyone who wants to learn how to develop for WordPress using PHP.

A minor recommendation, at this point, I wish the section in which dealing with menus is taught were longer and detailed particularly for dynamic menus.  This is how the real world works in which we cater to the client(s); be it in-house or otherwise.
results.content_html:
FINALLY! I had the time to invest to sit-down and go through the course, step-by-step. I gave myself the goal of knocking-down a section of the course per day.

The course is well-detailed and gave me a great perspective on how to develop Web sites using WordPress as their platform. It helped dispel, and clarify, and shed light into many unknowns and unclear issues which I had, up until that point.

The instructor is meticulous to let one know about pitfalls, how to best avoid them and, whenever available, how to make sure not to run into similar pitfalls in the future.

I had worked with WordPress in the past, prior to taking this course. However, it was in a highly demanding environment, and under the worst of conditions. I really did not have the opportunity to sit-down and learn to develop PHP code for WordPress. There was just a blind demand for results from someone who was a PHP developer but certainly knew nothing about WordPress development.

Again, the course is PERFECT! I strongly recommend it to anyone who wants to learn how to develop for WordPress using PHP.

A minor recommendation, at this point, I wish the section in which dealing with menus is taught were longer and detailed particularly for dynamic menus. This is how the real world works in which we cater to the client(s); be it in-house or otherwise.

results.content:
Excellent course. I loved how Brad takes the time to explain everything instead of just copy-pasting from another screen and teaching the concepts instead of saying just do this and do that. Surprisingly there was a lot more JavaScript involved in the course than I first imagined but it was great to improve my JavaScript skills along with my WordPress skills.

The only recommendation I have is dedicating a chapter to database management like how to keep it organized, how to find info in the MySQL database, maybe some basic SQL syntax. Other than that, great work.

results.content:
So far the course is excellent.  The instructor takes the time to thoroughly explain things that people who have never programmed before need to understand.

There is so much information it is unbelievable.  The course certainly is showing me what is possible with WordPress.  Could I do this on my own - NO!  Everything is done by rote so what is learned at the detail level is minimal.  The concept of looking up functions is great but if you don't know what to look up, how do you find out?

Also, I think somewhere fairly early there should be a lesson on 'How to debug the code'.  I have spent a lot of time looking for errors which are a simple punctuation or spelling error. at least twice I have had to copy the file from resources to eliminate the error.  That doesn't teach me a thing.
results.content_html:

results.content: There is no update since 2018. Therefore, the course is overall awful especially for the people who are almost halfway through the course and realize there is no fix out there especially from the teacher's side when you are completely stuck using old material that doesn't even exist on the web. And another noticeable thing is through out the course the instructor keeps saying 'don't worry about it now, you will get to know it later', leaving a complete new term unexplained. It is understandable that WordPress has couple of hundreds builtin functions and the instructor may not be able to go over every single ones, but he could have showed more rigid examples by constraining functions to a less number and well explained. Therefore, at the end of the course you will never remember what you have done,and wouldn't be able to guess what are the most commnly used functions. Finally this course is not followable if the gulf.js file, setting.js, webpack.config.js can not be configured properly. I am completely dissapointed as I invested about 15days of time to follow this course and had to give up.

If you don't have your environment setup EXACTLY like his, you are going to have problem after problem.  I have no idea why an instructor teaching a basic subject like this would inject such a biased and unnecessarily complex and brittle approach to coding.
results.content_html:
Found this course on YouTube. Starting out it was concise and built on each lecture beautifully. Loved it.

Then came along the automated workflow tools as well as bizarre css and javascript coding framework. What does Node.js and Gulp have to do with basic wordpress development???

If you don't have your environment setup EXACTLY like his, you are going to have problem after problem. I have no idea why an instructor teaching a basic subject like this would inject such a biased and unnecessarily complex and brittle approach to coding.

One of the best Wordpress training but know that you will face some problems that you need to solve yourself.

What was good about this training?
In depth training and explanation.

What could be improved:
There are some really frustrating time consuming 'bugs'  in the course/setting if you don't use the exact setup as the instructor and you can't expect any support from the trainer! I lost a lot of time with it.
Lucky I had some peers who helped me.
There are some packages used that makes the creation of the site more complex to beginners.

results.content: Superb presentation -- The author's clarity and ability to present concepts simply are one of the best if not the best I've seen.  The presentation style of no-nonsense directly focused explanations with a nod toward generality gives the student reason to pack away the knowledge for future use without impacting the immediate use of it.   I know PHP quite well and so it is a great help to see how WordPress has leveraged its capabilities, formalized a website/blog construction approach by (mostly) separating the semantics from the presentation.

results.content:
Going a little too fast when imputing php code.  Some of us don't type as quickly as the instructor because we're not as familiar with the php language as he is.

I had to lower my rating.  Starting with Section 13, the lessons become bogged down with JQuery and JSON stuff which I didn't know was going to be part of the course.  It's really dry stuff and the instructor goes way too in-depth for my skill level.  Having no warning that this much JQuery was going to be part of the course was disappointing.  I would not have paid for this course otherwise.

I think the instructor needs to separate building the "Search" feature into another entire course clearing telling anyone interested that it will include a lot of JQuery and JSON.  This is more for advanced students.

results.content:
Prior to taking this course, I had dabbled in Drupal and static HTML/CSS sites, but had no real experience with web development beyond that. Within 5 months of taking this course, along with Brad's Front End Developer course, I was working full-time as a Front End Developer for a major research University, and was making significantly better money than I had in my old career. 

Much of that is due to Brad's courses.

There are a lot of excellent developers on youtube and here on Udemy that have courses packed full of useful information—and the vast majority of them are useless, hot garbage to the average viewer. 

Brad is an excellent, experienced teacher, and it shows in the way he structures his lessons and shapes his demonstrations. He has a rare ability to know exactly what piece of information you need to have right when you need it. I've bought all of his courses, and will likely continue to do so.

results.content:
Just completed the course apart from the Extra Credit section. I have completed a few courses on Wordpress, and I feel this is the best one for learning Wordpress development. 
The Fictional University site you build in the course is VERY comprehensive. I really feel confident that I have learnt enough to produce a very substantial website for most scenarios. The course has provided me with a deep understanding of how the backend of Wordpress hangs together, and has fantastic examples of powerful features – such as Custom Post Types, Custom Queries, REST API use and Custom REST API creation.
The course clearly covers setting up of your own development environment and workflow (including deployment) – which is FANTASTIC! I love Brad’s clean, clear and organised design. Security is also covered.
Brad’s presentation is second to none. This is the third course of Brad’s I have done, and they would have to be my favourites. He explains more complex concepts with easy to follow examples. Unlike other courses he will explain why he takes certain approaches to development, rather than just doing it and you are left scratching your head, and having to google separately. He also responds to all questions and comments quickly.

I look forward to any new courses that Brad produces as I would be confident that I would learn a lot as well as having a lot of fun along the way.

results.content: This course was not only the best course I've taken on Udemy, it was the best computer programming educational experience I've ever had.  Brad has developed this course expertly, with a coverage of the field and pacing that set the standard for developer education everywhere.  The full program is 27 hours and not a minute of it is wasted with typos or debugging, or fluff, or off-tangent material.  The lecture series sets a deliberate course from creating the first folder to managing multiple web projects on local machines, hitting every essential aspect in WordPress, JavaScript, REST, and the Git workflow.  I truly cannot say enough good things about this course - I only wish he had ten more courses in the catalog.  You will NOT regret the time and money invested in this course.

results.content:
An excellent, comprehensive introduction to Wordpress and many of it's features.

The teaching style is very engaging and in-depth, working from a prefabricated start point, adding features in a code-along fashion.

Coming to this as a computing graduate, I found the curriculum to be very well balanced, covering the majority of the Wordpress features required to develop real-world sites with the advanced functionality that the modern web demands.

Thanks Brad, "let's keep things rolling", and I'll see you in the next course.

results.content:
If I could give this course more than 5 stars, I absolutely would.  This is by far one of the best courses I've taken on Udemy, and definitely the best WordPress development course that I have taken hands-down.  I am walking away from this course feeling great about everything that I have learned, confident that I will be able to use it in projects moving forward, and excited to see what I can now build.

Brad is a fantastic instructor!  The explanations are well-paced and easy to understand.  At some point in the course it all began to 'click' and the repetition of creating custom queries and page templates really helped to solidify my understanding.  I would strongly recommend this course to anyone that is interested in learning more about WordPress development.  You will be so glad that you jumped in!

More than that, the workflow that Brad introduced has really helped me step up my game, and I am looking forward to continuing on in his other course to learn more about Git and how to set up a workflow to really let my projects take off.

results.content:
It's probably one of the best teachers I've seen. However, his coding style is pretty sloppy (e.g. his naming of variables and functions is awful, no care for white space or alignment, and omg when he mentions clean code).

The takeaway is that this is a course to learn Wordpress, not clean code, so these issues are secondary: it's still an excellent introduction to WP and WP theming. But I just can't give him that fifth star, when it hurts my eyes all too often to watch him type code.

results.content:
Beware, this is NOT a course for beginners! The teacher is constantly using html without any explanations and assuming you already know and use html (he even says things like: "your instinct might be to do [this or that] - yeah, right, html "instinct" for beginners?!)". He's moving VERY fast and you can't follow AND type code at the same time when you are not used to it. You have to constantly go back and forth between the Udemy window in your browser, the window with your personal version, the visual code editor, the finder, that's crazy. 
Also, and most importantly, what on earth is the point of not using the WP themes if all we are doing here is to "create" a theme based on a template we know nothing about? We keep copying and pasting lines of code we did not create nor understand. You either use pre-existing themes and templates or you do really create on from scratch, but there's no point being in-between. 
And the instructor doesn't even bother to respond to bad reviews, as you can see. 
I wish I had paid more attention to the bad reviews and most of all I wish I could have started the course before the end of the 30-Day Money-Back Guarantee. 
Waste of time and money... (first time it happens to me on Udemy)

results.content: I've been a professional dev for over 20 years. In my time I've experienced many book and online trainings for any number of development technologies. Most suffer from either a really smart dev rambling to show off, or lazy devs with poor communication skills and broken code examples.  This tutorial suffers from neither.  Instead, excellent teacher, concise visual demonstrations, solid content and code (so far ;).  Well worth the price!  Learned a ton so far is just one evening.  Can't wait to finish.

results.content:
Absolutely Awesome and Exciting!!! Buy it, you will not regret it.
This is a great experience for me. I am a developer with 22+ years experience and for a compelling reason out of being annoyed and aggravated by someone, i decided to take a crash course in WP to work on a project i was going outsource to them. I always thought WP as a widget/drag and drop based tool and was not interested since i was used to coding from the beginning and having absolute control over the behavior of the applications i developed.
As a result, the title of this Course peeked my interest and i must say, boy, am i glad i made that leap. 
The pace and the Instructional detail has kept me so engaged that i can't wait to get back at it whenever i have some time on my hands.
One of the strongest plus for me about Brad's style, is how he will explain a step whenever he walks you through an example if even he has done it before. And i think that is very valuable because if you are a total newbie, by the time you are finished, you will certainly remember that "thing" he had walked you through.
The pace is just perfect but if you are following and working through the course, you'll find yourself pausing a lot.
I feel like a Pro and i'm only halfway through the course. I am really excited!
results.content_html:
Absolutely Awesome and Exciting!!! Buy it, you will not regret it.
This is a great experience for me. I am a developer with 22+ years experience and for a compelling reason out of being annoyed and aggravated by someone, i decided to take a crash course in WP to work on a project i was going outsource to them. I always thought WP as a widget/drag and drop based tool and was not interested since i was used to coding from the beginning and having absolute control over the behavior of the applications i developed.
As a result, the title of this Course peeked my interest and i must say, boy, am i glad i made that leap.
The pace and the Instructional detail has kept me so engaged that i can't wait to get back at it whenever i have some time on my hands.
One of the strongest plus for me about Brad's style, is how he will explain a step whenever he walks you through an example if even he has done it before. And i think that is very valuable because if you are a total newbie, by the time you are finished, you will certainly remember that "thing" he had walked you through.
The pace is just perfect but if you are following and working through the course, you'll find yourself pausing a lot.
I feel like a Pro and i'm only halfway through the course. I am really excited!

While the basic examples are informative, you could never go from this course to say writing your own complete theme or plugin. It doesn't address true independent plugin/theme development. results.content: I think it is well presented, clear to follow and meets my expectations so far. A couple of points for improvement, 1 I would like to see more mini challenges to use the knowledge I have gained to do some things myself, I find that this is the best way to solidify what I have learnt (I am tending to pauze the video and trying to do the next bit myself, so I create my own challenges).   2. I think it would be hard for someone who did not know the basics of html, css, and general programming to follow everything, so therefore, I find it strange that sometimes some of the basics are explained, for example how to comment out something in html, when this course clearly has a pre-requisite for having that basic knowledge. I understand wanting to make it accessible to all, so maybe separating some of those basics out, so I could easily skip the non relevant things.  Overall I'm very pleased so far.

results.content:
I love Brad's delivery - it's a pleasure following the videos. He is very thorough and covers his topics very well. I'm learning a lot - new to PHP and seeing how powerful it is. Yes, I know it's an old technology, but it's in so much current software that it should be around for years to come, so I'm really glad that at last I'm learning it from such a nice, knowledgeable instructor! 
Of course it's not just PHP in this course. Brad explains the inner workings of WordPress so you're able to customise your website the way you like. 
I'm only on one of the early sections of the course, and it looks like there is a great deal more here including JavaScript, the REST API and how to deploy the project.

results.content:
This is a really excellent course. The pace and depth of explanations are fantastic and the material covered is extremely useful. I've been working with WordPress for a few years and this is the first time certain things have "clicked" for me. I'm now starting to see the real power of the platform.

My only complaints so far are the use of "advanced" things like Gulp and class-based Javascript. I get they're important but they introduce so many opportunities for error that have nothing to do with the content of the course itself. I've had zero problem following the course material BUT I have had to deal with a few issues with Gulp and some confusion regarding the class-based Javascript. Just doing everything in straightforward Vanilla JS without jQuery or a bundler might have been a better approach.

Still think this course is worth every penny.

results.content:
I am seriously suspicious of the positive reviews on here. I find it odd how the 1/2 star reviews reflect my experience and the 5 star reviews seem to be completely oblivious to the challenges I and others have faced. None of these 5 star reviewers seemed to be active on the course forum and actually the course forums are now pretty much dead. BTW count on absolutely no support from the course author Brad (who is a great teacher but doesn't often provide forum support). Here are some of the problems I've experienced....
1. The latter transition to the JQuery-less alternative implementation comes across as an after-thought and was poorly implemented with no line by line explanations of what or why. Completely in contrast to the authors original stellar efforts in this course.
2. The Q&A support here is non-existent, no tutor interaction, no teaching assistant, no discord or slack.
3. No CSS, JS or HTML is taught to any depth so you will need to learn this if you want to do everything you see on this course on your own. Not a criticism as this course would have to be 3 or 4 times longer and this isn't practical. 
4. Majority of people have big problems with the automation section of the course so count on some problems. Node and the packages we use could easily be another course so again you'll implement here but don't expect to understand it. Again not a criticism just making you aware.
5. Course is old and is struggling to be relevant. If Brad had redone the course using JS instead of JQuery but offered it as a new second improved course I would have been happy to pay again. I'm hoping he will do this when the big changes to WP are implemented this year 2021.

I could go on and I strongly suggest you look very closely at the 1/2 star reviews for a more balanced critique of this course because the 5 star reviews sound a bit flaky to me. This was a great course but now going over it a year later again it's creaking!! Brad is a great teacher it's just a shame his latest effort with trying to update this course was so half hearted. Would I look at doing further courses from Brad, most likely yes.

4. Majority of people have big problems with the automation section of the course so count on some problems. Node and the packages we use could easily be another course so again you'll implement here but don't expect to understand it. Again not a criticism just making you aware.
5. Course is old and is struggling to be relevant. If Brad had redone the course using JS instead of JQuery but offered it as a new second improved course I would have been happy to pay again. I'm hoping he will do this when the big changes to WP are implemented this year 2021.

I could go on and I strongly suggest you look very closely at the 1/2 star reviews for a more balanced critique of this course because the 5 star reviews sound a bit flaky to me. This was a great course but now going over it a year later again it's creaking!! Brad is a great teacher it's just a shame his latest effort with trying to update this course was so half hearted. Would I look at doing further courses from Brad, most likely yes.

results.content: Been through a few iterations of this course. Hence I've re-rated the course from almost 5 stars to 2.5 stars. Nothing wrong with Brad's skill, it's just the lacksadaisical attitude to students having problems.

results.content:
This course was definitely more than I was expecting. After working with WordPress as a Jr. Developer for a year and learning mostly from quick online tutorials, I had a mixed opinion on WordPress and the way it worked with developers. However, this course opened my eyes to how flexible and powerful the platform is. I can safely say that this course not only has saved me hundreds of hours of research, it has also allowed me to fully understand the potential of features like custom plugins, the Rest API and WordPress' own query.

I totally recommend this course for any new developers who want to familiarize with wordpress, I guarantee it will satisfy you beyond your expectations.

results.content:
Okay so this course is full of critical information that is either entirely missing, or so briefly glossed over early in the course that it's forgotten by the student later when it's actually important to understand.

There are several items that need to be updated (eg: post urls no longer contain the archive url in them).

The css provided does not match that in the lessons when he says it does.

Towards the very beginning of the course he walks you through setting up the "automated workflow", which at that point amounts to saving you from clicking the refresh button. However, it seems to break everything more often than not. After having everything working fine... the styles just randomly stopped loading. Creating a giant headache. 
TIP: Skip the automating workflow process until the very end, if you even want to do it at all. It is not at all worth the time it takes or the headaches it causes (he's got several lessons just about fixing the variety of things that will most likely break when you try to set up the automated workflow). Seriously...just keep clicking the refresh button.

To top off all the major flaws the JavaScript instructions are incomplete. The way he tells you to import JavaScript doesn't work with the latest versions of wordpress. Other students have asked him about if and it's been 5 months and he hasn't responded. Terrible effort from an instructor.

And finally... this is not "For developers", this is for complete newbies. I already understand classes, functions, arrays, etc.... going over those items is a complete waste of my time. The only reason I selected this course was because the title included "For Developers", not "For liberal arts majors looking to change careers".

Overall, very disappointed...this is the worst course I have ever purchased on Udemy and will definitely be returning it.

results.content:
I was starting building up my website using plugins and themes. But I ran too many problems and conflicts between plugins and themes. After spending a lot of money, I desided to get my hand dirty and write my own plugin. And now I have it with only taking this class!!!

results.content:
This course is excellent for advanced techniques in using php and javascript to enhance Wordpress. You also get a good insight on how Wordpress is structured and creating custom post types.

It was a bit confusing at first regarding the local development environment. At the begining of the course it was suggested to use flywheel or MAMP, but in section 7, Brad started to talk about VirtualBox and Vagrant. I guess this was the perferred method when the course was first released.

Thanks Brad for a fantastic course, I'm looking forward to the Javascript course coming in 2019.

results.content:
The course did a solid job introducing you to WordPress development basics--I think I have a solid foundation to continue on now! The introduction to PHP was fairly easy, coming from JavaScript, and there are a lot of good techniques and tips in here for how to make certain things work together. WordPress is a massive beast, and Brad managed to make it simple enough to understand in a single course. I'll still need tons of practice to be any good at all, and frankly I'm not super-motivated because of how bulky and inelegant working with WP is compared to a MERN-stack app, but I took the course because a lot of people in my client base want WP skills, so I'll probably keep learning. 

I won't complain about the jQuery, since it is something you'll still find in a lot of older codebases and it was a good exercise for me to rewrite everything in Vanilla JS by myself. 

The one thing I would have liked would have been one or two small projects on top of this big one. Just little "practice spinning up a basic, functional site" or "practice integrating this feature into this existing site" side quests. I've found the best thing a course can do to get me comfortable with a concept is to repeat it a few times. By the time I ran npx create-react-app for the third time in my React course, I felt like I knew what I was doing, whereas when I finish a single large project like this one I feel like I've built something without 100% understanding how. 

I get that maintaining and updating a lot of smaller projects is hard, and the single big one taught me a lot--that's just my personal experience based on the way I learn best! Thanks for a good intro Brad--I'll keep working :)

results.content: I took this advanced course knowing absolutely zero about php, APIs, custom Wordpress templates, etc.. I just wanted to jump in the deep-end and get a sense of what customizing a WordPress site would entail. Brad's use of the demo university website is just great, as it's a real world, believable project. It gives so many good examples of what you might do with all these capabilities. He does refer to online resources you can use when you are off on your own projects, but his primary focus is always on building a new capability to the main fictional university website. Seeing how all these features can be applied in real life is motivating and very exciting. His teaching manner, pace and excellent speaking voice are so professional, and easy-going. I've seen nothing but praise for Brad, and he certainly deserves it. Thank you so much for the course!

results.content:
Absolutely the most comprehensive WordPress course that I have ever invested my time and money into.  

I have been learning Wordpress off and on for the past three years through videos (paid and free), books, and online tutorials.  I often find myself frustrated at the overall shallow depth that most instructors/authors provide in the content.  This is absolutely not the case with this course.  Brad Schiff walks through so many different aspects of Wordpress that are extremely important for developers to know because these aspects really enable developers to develop themes that go beyond the basics.  Equally important, Brad explains everything is in great detail so that you are left with an excellent understanding.  

I do recommend this course to WordPress/PHP beginners.  You will not have any issues following along with what Brad presents.  

If you are new to HTML and CSS, you can still take this course but personalizing the theme will be difficult without the knowledge of HTML and CSS.  Nonetheless, you will still benefit from this course if your goal is solely to learn more about WordPress theme development because Brad provides all of the HTML and CSS in the resources section.  

Overall, I highly recommend this course to anyone that desires developing WordPress themes.

Overall, I highly recommend this course to anyone that desires developing WordPress themes.

results.content:
Some of the content is out of date now.  The author uses jQuery, which is ok in itself, but not forward thinking, and he suggests instead (not part of the course) you can use one of the big 3 front end frameworks to replace jQuery.  This isn't true, you just need ES6 to do a like-for-like.  So a shame to not embrace ES6 here.

There are at least 3 places where the code is poor and the design doesn't make sense, and a few places where its just outright wrong, which in all but one instance is because things have moved on in the years since this course was written.

Sorry Brad, its a good course, except you've let it slowly become out of date.

Oh, one last gripe, the way he uses CSS pre-written is as pain, yes I can see why, as it isn't a course on CSS, but it abstracts a little away from the objective of the course for the sake of making it pretty, and sometimes things are conveniently working, leaving people scratching their head a lot when they come to something similar in the future.

If I took this course a couple of years ago, I'd probably give it 4/5.

results.content:
I picked up this course to bring myself up to speed with WordPress for my job as a Jr. Developer. I've never worked with WordPress before and I can understand why businesses use it. It's a great tool to quickly build websites with speed in mind for the client. I like that it includes a nice admin area that you don't have to build from scratch. 

While working through the course I've gotten comfortable with the WordPress ecosystem. Learning about the WordPress Rest API has opened my eyes to new possibilities. The end project is also portfolio worthy. I likely wont take a course if I don't like the project being built. In my honest opinion, this is a great course that will put you on a whole new level when it comes to WordPress Development. Once you complete the course your confidence with building WordPress sites will skyrocket. You will definitely feel like a pro.

results.content: The videos have a great pace and are easy to follow. I like how there are advanced and intermediate/beginner level options. However, the captions are auto-generated, which kind of sucks... results.content: Totally screwed me up in the Automation section. Loading Flywheel at the beginning of the course made me assume that it was the environment that we were working in, then switching gears to Vagrant, I ended mixing the two environments together and was left with nothing that worked properly. Extremely disappointed in this course.

results.content:
I've been building custom WP themes for about 2 years now, and even for me this course has been nothing but gold so far (about 40% in). Brad talks a bit slow, but for me that has been no problem as you can simply breeze through at 1.5/2x speed if you're already familiar with some of the topics.

It's already taught me some great additional knowledge and workflows. The course price is peanuts compared to the knowledge and understanding you gain from it.

I can't wait to finish the course and up my WP-developer skills. It'll be extremely valuable to what I can offer my clients.

results.content: This course moves along at a good pace, which is what I was looking for as a refresher for me on theme development for WordPress. Be warned he does not discuss CSS at all, so it may be a bit confusing when he is doing his layout with his own custom CSS, also the drop-down menu is not covered. This being said, his teaching style and knowledge is fantastic! If you already know some PHP you will get even more out of this course. He covers PHP in a very interesting style of "showing you" rather than some boring lesson. I would say the focus, of course, is on using WordPress functions. This is one of the best WordPress development courses on Udemy.

results.content: I was trying to short-cut my way into becoming a WordPress developer without really deep-diving into the WordPress core API. I thought just knowing how to use tools like page builders was enough to become a true WordPress professional. Boy I was so wrong! No sooner had I taken this course than did I discover the true power and magic of WordPress. The content is layout in a concise and fun way to learn WordPress, even the most complex (and weird) parts are easy to grasp and digest. I highly recommend this course, especially if you are a beginner looking to jump-start your career in becoming a true WordPress developer.

results.content:
I'm enjoying this course a great deal. I'm hearing-impaired and have a hard time with video, but his speech is nice and clear. I don't think there have been any parts I couldn't hear so far.

My only complaint is that he waits too long to clear things up, like when the site doesn't load, etc. I had to wonder why my site didn't load and then noticed there was text at the top instead of him saying it, so it was probably added later.

I'm kind of dreading the coding parts because of it since it's not a cool feeling to have a disparity between my code and his code and not know why. So... I'm hoping that part goes better. Looking at the comments from confused people has me a little worried, tho. I'm hoping I can learn what I came here to learn.
results.content_html:
I'm enjoying this course a great deal. I'm hearing-impaired and have a hard time with video, but his speech is nice and clear. I don't think there have been any parts I couldn't hear so far.

My only complaint is that he waits too long to clear things up, like when the site doesn't load, etc. I had to wonder why my site didn't load and then noticed there was text at the top instead of him saying it, so it was probably added later.

I'm kind of dreading the coding parts because of it since it's not a cool feeling to have a disparity between my code and his code and not know why. So... I'm hoping that part goes better. Looking at the comments from confused people has me a little worried, tho. I'm hoping I can learn what I came here to learn.

Overall, it was a very engaging experience.  The teacher is very clear with the topics and knows a lot about the subject.

Sometimes it got a little basic for me, so if you are an experienced developer you must know that very basics are going to be explained, so all people can follow the course (what is a function, what is a conditional, etc.)

I strongly recommend this course to anyone who is new to Wordpress Development. You will not only scratch the surface of Wordpress, but you will also even learn some extra useful tools to make your development easier.

Thank you, Brad.

Outstanding instructor skills! It's clear from the first lecture.

Brad CLEARLY enunciates his words and does a world class job of managing student expectations and framing the context of the topics being taught. It's a minor quality, but his even and measured manner of speaking allows you to play the course at 1.5x without missing any words.

results.content:
Great course that delivers on its promise and helped me get up to speed with WordPress and modern day web developing techniques.

Improvement points:
- Google Maps API
Nowadays getting an API key for Google Maps requires setting up a billing account and provide credit-card data. It shouldn't be necessary to do so for a training. Since I didn't want to create billing and had to spend some time to work around that, to get the Campus Maps to work somewhat.

Google site said: "Reminder: To use the Maps JavaScript API, you must get an API key and you must enable billing. You can enable billing when you get your API key (see the Quick guide) or as a separate process (see Usage and Billing)"

- Sorting events
Sorting events on date doesn't work properly if you have a different locale than US. E.g. in Europe, the default date format is mm/dd/YYYY.

results.content:
Only real issue for me was that there was no provision for a beginner level install on Linux. The VirtualBox/Vagrant setup supplied at the start would not work, and I had to find a way to install on Linux from scratch. I am a professional developer so this was not too onerous, but might be problematic for someone less experienced.

There was a good deal of assumed knowledge about CSS and Javascript, but I guess that's fair enough.

This has given me a good introduction upon which I can build further.

results.content: Awesome course. A well constructed in-depth, methodical journey into adopting industry standard contemporary working practices. While developing a functional WordPress site and all this entails. Brad never shy's away from the hard stuff which may create issues with some students as to follow along using his optimal workflow requires a not to considerable amount focus and attention on the students part.  Trial and error. But once the student overcomes said obstacles Brad opens the window into the other side.  Not too many courses on this platform deliver this. A professionally orientated end-product for serious students who require the right authoritative information by an industry expert, delivering the necessary workflow and fundamental skill sets needed to be taken seriously in the industry.  I particularly enjoyed the sections on automated workflow, Gulp, Virtualbox and Vagrant , building custom REST API's,  Post type relationships and Deployment.  In fact the whole course is wall to wall quality and I can't thank Brad enough for the opportunity to 'peek' behind the veil and introducing us into the world of what it takes to be an actual professional WordPress developer. Cheers.

results.content:
The instructor breaks concepts down to their simplest form without doing what most programming instructors do - which is talk WAY over your head. This is natural because they've been in the industry so long they can't relate to what it's like to be a beginner. But it's not what happens in this course.

I love the way the teacher builds upon each concept as you're actually building something. It's real and you're up and building right away, not going over theory then jumping into impossible tasks. In my experience, very few instructors have this knack.

Reading other people's question helps in earlier stages. However in later lessons, there are less questions from others that can be helpful for your errors. Mostly you need to solve by your own. Having asked quesitons, you won't get reply or reply comes several days or sometime week after.

results.content:
Just finished the course to completion. Wow. Brad connected the dots where other tutorials, courses, etc had not. Even if the course stopped at the halfway point, it would have been worth my time and investment. Excellent course and highly recommend for those that want to get their head around wordpress. Brad is very thorough and does an excellent job of explaining.

However, that said, there is a slight issue, but I feel this prepares you for the developer life of troubleshooting and debugging so I do not detract from my rating. Setup the dev environment as he describes. If you use an alternate setup (as I did), you may struggle a bit more in certain areas, but usually there's someone else that had the issue as well in the Q/A section.

Brad is very thorough and does an excellent job of explaining.

However, that said, there is a slight issue, but I feel this prepares you for the developer life of troubleshooting and debugging so I do not detract from my rating. Setup the dev environment as he describes. If you use an alternate setup (as I did), you may struggle a bit more in certain areas, but usually there's someone else that had the issue as well in the Q/A section.

results.content:
Outstanding course! Brad is one of the best teachers I've seen. His courses strike a very good balance between advanced concepts, fully explained, and at the same time leading a novice through all the fundamentals clearly and concisely without too much detail. Not easy to accomplish, but he pulls it off. Not only that, but his visual designs are excellent, which you don’t often find with a lot of instructors.

As a long time graphic designer and web developer myself, I have worn many hats over the years and am now going through a lot of courses and tutorials to fill in the gaps of my knowledge to do more web development and programming, with a focus on WordPress. I find that Brad's courses perfectly fit my needs as he always emphasizes the best modern practices and workflows, and explains why he does what he does. I am also enrolled in his "Git a Web Developer Job" and I highly recommend both.

results.content:
It's okay!

There's a lot of information to process.

I feel like this course goes through a LOT! I definitely learnt how to build a Wordpress site from scratch.

I think the style of this course is very much "Follow along", and utilizes a lot of repetition to let concepts sink in. Which is OK.

However, from a personal stand point--theory is something I generally struggle with. This course has a lot of it, however the jargon is broken down into language I understood.

I feel this was a good starting point for learning Wordpress!

However, I feel that the structure of this course isn't suited as a future reference point.

I think, this course is for you if you want to learn Wordpress Development, and you struggle understanding tech-jargon.

However, I would buy another course to use as a reference point.

Overall, the course decent and I have no buyer regrets.

results.content:
At first the course seemed to be amazing and I gave 5 starts without hesitation. Brad is nice a instructor! However, after the lesson 46 it became too difficult to follow. I'm not able to work on more difficult tasks that require JavaScript, REST API, etc. as I feel that's already an advanced level.

Seems like Brad disappeared over a year ago from the help section and doesn't reply to student inquiries, thus there's no help in need. Some information is also slightly outdated, for example Google Maps now require your credit card information if you want to use it on your website even for a practice.

I was able to complete & enjoy about 60% of the total course. The knowledge gained from the first half of the course is extremely valuable for a total beginner, nevertheless, not being able to fully complete all the tasks successfully makes me a bit disappointed. 

I got this course with a huge discount so all in all I'm ok with the purchase.

results.content:
This course is excellent! It goes from the very beginning and covers what I've found to be more than enough to create a variety of sites easily. As the title says it really unblocks the power of Wordpress (which can be really powerful) via coding.
On top of that the lectures are well paced, very clear and well explained and with good examples as we build the university project. You'll even learn a couple of things about Javascript which is also great.
I took half a star from the rating simply due to the lack of responses on the Q&A, but to be fair I'd feel discouraged to answer them as well seeing that most are lazy people who want all the work done for them.

results.content:
Brad Schiff is one of my absolute favourite online teachers. That's because he is able to understand how a beginner is struggling with programming. There are a lot of concepts a senior developer takes for granted, but to teach it to others is a great skill and Brad has that. He is explaining every detail in a very responsible way. 

This course contains not only basic to advanced Wordpress skills but also a lot of general web programming knowledge. So no matter where you come from you will grow as a developer.

As it is very comprehensive make sure to take notes. If you just code along and then look back at earlier lessons you may have forgotten the "why" and "how". It's also a great idea to push your code for each lesson to your own Git repo so that you can go back and see how the code has evolved. 

This is by far the best Wordpress course I have seen and I can also recommend the Wordpress playlist on LearnWebCode, which is Brad's Youtube channel. Thanks Brad!

results.content:
Very clear instructions and tutorials. Good pace. Instructor communicates clearly and the audio/video quality is high.

Update - after completing course

Now that I've finished the course I appreciate even more how much information Brad was able to teach in such an engaging way. His examples were easy to follow and he provided excellent explanations not just on how to do something, but "why" to do it. He emphasized best practices for coding instead of quick & dirty shortcuts. 

I highly recommend this course!

results.content:
If you have some experience with Wordpress and would like to step up to the next level by customizing your sites and developing themes, this is the course for you.  There are MANY Udemy courses on this topic.  THIS is the one you should take.  It is taught by Brad Schiff, one of the premiere instructors on Udemy.  His courses are, in my estimate, among the very best online courses available on the Internet.  

Brad is a master of cutting edge software development and his pretensions are authoritative.  These courses are organized around a logical and comprehensive treatment of his subject and are impeccably presented.  He speaks in a pleasantly didactic style, 
paced for the listener's understanding. His lectures are recorded and edited so that the timing of the typing, mousing, and highlighting of text in the video follow the audio tracks EXACTLY.  All this makes for a pleasant and efficient learning  experience.

Brad is a gifted teacher and posesses the ability to explain difficult concepts with extraordinary clarity.  Concepts that used to seem difficult seem simple after Brad is done explaining them.  Also, I have found that the ability to reach out for help and to get it quickly is critical to a successful learning experience.  If you are having problems, Brad is generous with his time, answering questions patiently, clearly, and quickly. 

While Brad explains all the php and javascript thoroughly, a working knowledge of html is important.  If you are not yet conversant in html/css, Brad's course, "Web Design for Beginners" would be well worth the investment before diving into this challenging  material.

In addition to explaing all things Wordpress, Brad also introduces us to concepts in workflow automation, running a proxy server with build tasks under the control of GULP, a nifty little scripting tool.  He also shows you how to set up an environment for running Wordpress on your local machine and uses Postman to examine http requests and responses.  Largely unaware of these tools before I started, now I can't imagine developing code without them.

The course develops a fictional university website.  It is fully responsive allowing pages to display correctly for all devices types (phone, tablet, pc...).  This is accomplished using CSS and Brad provides a resource file with all the CSS pre-written for us to use.  Very conciously Brad does not discuss the CSS in this course.  To have done so would have taken us way off topic and made to course overwhelming.  This way he keeps us tightly focused on the important matters of building out a website.  If you would like to understand how his CSS magically transforms the page to a format perfectly suited to whatever device you are using, please take his course, "Git Workflow."  That course is amazing!

Every lecture has a resource file with the finished code for that lecture.  That way you can more easiliy track down bugs
 
I find Brads courses to be incredibly informative and inspiring.  Take this course.  You will love it.

results.content:
I learned a lot in this course. I have been successfully building/hacking WP themes for a long time, and I learned the way many open-source fans do, by just getting the software and experimenting. Any self-taught person will have gaps in their knowledge, though, and I definitely picked up a lot of useful stuff in this course. 

My main intent was actually getting to understand the WordPress flavor of the REST API, and that was covered well. The other parts were more familiar to me, so it was great to be able to speed up the video - I double-timed my way through some sections. Speaking of that, the teacher speaks very slowly, and that could be helpful for people for whom English is not their first language. 

I will deduct one star due to the lack of response to some of my questions. I don't have a lot of questions as I'm very self-sufficient, but when I do ask I'd like an answer.

His quirky terminology is kind of funny... You "drop down" in the code to get the next line. I dropped down under my desk, and then I couldn't see the screen anymore. :) You "jump into" code. I tried that, and I busted my laptop!? :) "The name doesn't matter" - well, it does if you stomp on a function in a plugin, for instance. Pronouncing "get" like "git" - that sounds like an old western movie, and I thought at first that he was talking about GIT. 

This particular theme is especially "verbose", and I can see why many people go crazy with WP's gruesome mixture of PHP and HTML in templates. You have to be a good debugger to track down errors in these. I prefer cleaner base themes, although I suppose having a fashion-forward combo of CSS and HTML makes it easier to make a cute demo.

Any self-taught person will have gaps in their knowledge, though, and I definitely picked up a lot of useful stuff in this course.

My main intent was actually getting to understand the WordPress flavor of the REST API, and that was covered well. The other parts were more familiar to me, so it was great to be able to speed up the video - I double-timed my way through some sections. Speaking of that, the teacher speaks very slowly, and that could be helpful for people for whom English is not their first language.

I will deduct one star due to the lack of response to some of my questions. I don't have a lot of questions as I'm very self-sufficient, but when I do ask I'd like an answer.

His quirky terminology is kind of funny... You "drop down" in the code to get the next line. I dropped down under my desk, and then I couldn't see the screen anymore. :) You "jump into" code. I tried that, and I busted my laptop!? :) "The name doesn't matter" - well, it does if you stomp on a function in a plugin, for instance. Pronouncing "get" like "git" - that sounds like an old western movie, and I thought at first that he was talking about GIT.

This particular theme is especially "verbose", and I can see why many people go crazy with WP's gruesome mixture of PHP and HTML in templates. You have to be a good debugger to track down errors in these. I prefer cleaner base themes, although I suppose having a fashion-forward combo of CSS and HTML makes it easier to make a cute demo.

results.content:
This thorough, comprehensive course has taught me all I need to know to create my own custom theme, as well as create most any site I want in Wordpress. It goes far more in-depth than the other Wordpress courses I have taken, and has taught me the greater part of what it takes to become a Wordpress Developer.
Every section was packed full of useful methods, detailed instructions and in-depth explanations. 
The spaced repetition of concepts and methods throughout the lessons was useful for rememebering it all.
The do-it-yourself challenges at the end were useful for hands-on practice and building up competence.
Right from the beginning, I was impressed by how thoughtfully the lessons had embedded safety measures to help us avoid the most common technical difficulties. 
For the coding errors that slipped through, Brad was responsive and answered our questions in person, in a friendly tone, and with great pointers and solutions.
I was also impressed by how the sections were built up step by step, starting with what we already knew and the simple code we had already written, and then introducing new methods and revealing how it all came together into the more complex code that performed the more complex tasks.
Overall, I feel that I got great value out of this course. Thank you for a wonderful learning experience, Brad!
