results.content:
At the time I'm writing this, I just finished section 6, and yet this course has taught me so much. The course itself is broken down into nice bite-sized videos about important WordPress topics. He is excellent with his explanations and makes it easy for beginners to understand certain topics. I already had some PHP experience, but it wasn't difficult to skip through the parts that I knew and the times that I didn't skip, I was really impressed by his simplification and examples. 

Besides that, the course covers a lot of different areas, and you feel like you got more than your money's worth. The size might seem daunting, but even if you only get through half of the course, you will have learned a large chunk of what you need to create highly customizable themes.

I previously tried to create my own theme using a basic starter theme with little success. Everything was confusing, and I didn't understand why certain elements were there. I also tried creating a child theme but got frustrated with having to overwrite everything and not was too afraid to delete something for fear of breaking the code. After going through the first 6 sections, I'm way more confident in creating my own and actually understand why certain functions are being used. I'm excited to watch the later portions of his course since creating custom post types and fields is something that I always wondered about.

I already had some PHP experience, but it wasn't difficult to skip through the parts that I knew and the times that I didn't skip, I was really impressed by his simplification and examples.

Besides that, the course covers a lot of different areas, and you feel like you got more than your money's worth. The size might seem daunting, but even if you only get through half of the course, you will have learned a large chunk of what you need to create highly customizable themes.

I previously tried to create my own theme using a basic starter theme with little success. Everything was confusing, and I didn't understand why certain elements were there. I also tried creating a child theme but got frustrated with having to overwrite everything and not was too afraid to delete something for fear of breaking the code. After going through the first 6 sections, I'm way more confident in creating my own and actually understand why certain functions are being used. I'm excited to watch the later portions of his course since creating custom post types and fields is something that I always wondered about.

results.content: I would say I am pretty well-versed with WordPress and webdevelopment. I know about Gulp and I build my themes from scratch. I do like to learn new methods or newer ways to keep up or to expand my approach. Brad is a very good teacher. He explains every step very clearly. There's no argument there. However, there are some things that need to be said. If you have questions, you have to wait a while to get an answer. A while means weeks. Secondly, you need to go through every video. All the information is related. I was particularly interested in the WP Rest details and also the deployment. I skipped right to it and it didn't make much sense to me so I found myself going through the videos on how Brad set up the custom post types. So, the good thing about this whole course is I did learn some new methods and Brad is a good teacher if you haven't had the experience. The negative is that at times it seems a bit much, the code seemed a bit wonky - because when I tried it out (the exact same way), it didn't work and I got a bunch of errors. I wasn't the only one - the Q&A's were full of it. Get this course at a discount, then it's worth it.

results.content: Good course. It delivers on its promise. One thing I had hoped was that we'd go into a bit more detail on the PHP side of things. Don't get me wrong - there's a lot of PHP! It's just all WordPress related. We don't delve deep into the language itself. But don't let that stop you. This course goes into great depth on WordPress itself, and what you can do with it beyond the basic drag-and-drop functionality. The instructor is also clearly well versed in everything he teaches us. From PHP, to WordPress, to JavaScript, and even stuff that's completely out of the scope of the course,  like Gulp and NodeJS. If you're the kind of person that 'develops' WordPress sites with from the admin panel, and you'd like to know what more it has to offer, this is probably Pandora's box for you right here. I just wish the 'intro to PHP' stuff would have been a bit more detailed.

results.content:
I completed watching the entire course. I feel empowered as a WordPress developer after learning so much from this course. Once you learn the inner workings of WordPress, the possibilities are endless. You can build almost anything you can imagine.

WordPress is an important CMS which powers more than 25% of websites on the entire internet.  There are tons of job and freelancing opportunities if you master WordPress. 

In addition to the course project, I have also started developing WordPress themes which has led me to solidify the concepts learnt throughout the course. 

Brad is an amazing teacher who has explained all the WordPress concepts with great patience and simplified it for students to understand it in a better way. 

This course is a goldmine. I highly recommend it if you are an aspiring WordPress developer.

I request Brad to bring out a new course on topics such as WordPress plugin development with OOP PHP, Gutenberg block development and Headless WordPress.

Thank you Brad. Lots of love from India !

results.content:
En effet le formateur parle lentement, et j'ai du lutter à certains moments pour rester concentrer sans que mes yeux se ferment. 
Cependant son élocution est parfaite, et ce rythme permet de le comprendre à 100%.
De mon point de vue cette lenteur ressentie vient du fait que je ne suis pas un total débutant. Si on part du principe que Brad voulait faire une formation complète WordPress 0 to Héro pour débutant, le résultat est proche de la perfection.
Dans un monde idéal, il aurait été agréable de trouver une formation de qualité équivalente, avec le même contenu, mais orientée pour développeur junior. En attendant, je suis très heureux de celle-ci.

results.content:
My work is building SPAs with JavaScript, but my new job requires some WordPress development as well. I was not looking forward to using WordPress, but that was because I was ignorant to how powerful it is. 

I also thought WordPress was a dying powerhouse, but I see that there's a log of really cool stuff cropping up for the future of WordPress; node, React, graphQL, etc.

Finally, I probably would not have loved WordPress without Brad's enthusiasm and skill. 

Because I'm not new to development, I just watched his lectures at 3X speed and observed how similar WordPress was to my SPA development. Moreover, he illustrated it's powerful features. To practice WP, I simply created my own WordPress sites.

Thanks for being a great teacher!

Finally, if you're new and want to become a developer. Pay attention to the Vagrant setup. When I was starting out, setting up Vagrant was so confusing for me. I would've loved to get some help from Brad!
results.content_html:

Thanks for being a great teacher!

Finally, if you're new and want to become a developer. Pay attention to the Vagrant setup. When I was starting out, setting up Vagrant was so confusing for me. I would've loved to get some help from Brad!

results.content:
This course is well presented, but problematic for a few reasons:

- Presentation of content is relatively slow; yes, it's aimed for absolute beginners, but the repetition of information is fairly excessive. A lot of these 20-30 minute videos I feel could easily be cut in half without losing any important information.

- This course covers only PHP, which is fine by itself, but a large portion of the early course material is just copy/pasting content with little explanation behind why.

- Some of the tools provided simply do not work, and some of the code is, at least in my opinion as a dev, is badly written - could make better use of functions and if/else statements.

This material isn't *bad*, but it could be done much better. Still useful as learning material, but if you are anything past an absolute beginner, expect to be twiddling your thumbs for a good portion of the video content.
results.content_html:

results.content: Highly recommend this course! Brad has got to be one of the most pleasant people to learn from period. He's super knowledgable and invests so much into each lesson for the benefit of his students. He brings a lot of passion which is contagious and makes learning fun. The course is a little outdated in some parts (Brad has made plenty of effort to keep it up to date) but it still feels like a band-aid solution in places which makes for a challenging time when you run into a hurdle that didn't exist at the time of filming. You also shouldn't expect much support for this course unfortunately, you'll have to rely on Google for that. Still insanely good value for your money!

results.content: The instructor is a professional at teaching and almost robotic which I think is very good for students having such dense information being dropped on us. It comforting in how predictable and methodical his way of teaching is. It feels like I know he is about to explain something or answer a question I may have. There is no sloppily glossing over a concept without taking the time to explain and address what may be confusing about it. The course is well-organized and I do not see any flaws in this course. The only thing is I think I need to take certain parts of the course over again because of how many things there are to learn! This isn't just Wordpress, you will learn the fundamentals of all types of tools for a developer to know such as Node.js, and NPM. Very much recommended.

results.content: This is a great course if you're new to php and Wordpress workflow. Unfortunately, this course is also starting to show its age and looks like the author is plugging holes in the dam with his fingers by making small updates over time. I still think it's worth the money when on sale, but beware of the legacy code that might hinder your growth.

results.content: Brad is a 5 star teacher, however this course was a little outdated (made in 2017) and I did run into some problems such as Gulp Watch not working with Java Script files. Brad did not respond to any student questions until I was about 75% through the course (he recently made announcements and answered a couple of questions from a few students). He did acknowledge that patches were needed and that he would update the course. With that being said, once the course is updated and some of latest questions are answered, this is easily a 5+ star rated course. Brad is such a great teacher with extensive knowlage and a fantastic demeanor. I look forward to continue referencing this class and signing up for all the other classes he has to offer. Difficulties aside, I feel this course is a game changer and has put me on the fast track to becoming a solid WordPress Developer.

results.content:
The instructor is certainly knowledgeable but has a tendency to talk too much. Sometimes that can be a good thing but, when you've heard the same incredibly detailed point 10 times, well, it gets old. Also, this course seems to be slightly outdated. While the instructor did add a new (hyper detailed) section on creating custom blocks with WP 5.0, I found myself and a lot of other students running into issues (especially with Javascript) despite matching the coding and steps perfectly. It seems there are some back end compatibility issues not addressed directly in the course material.

Don't get me wrong. This is a good course but it takes a huge time commitment especially given the instructor's presentation style, maybe more than it should speaking honestly. It could also stand to be revamped more or less from the beginning especially now that WP 5.0 has been released. If found updating to 5.0 set forth the gremlins on my local site.

All in all, though. I would sign up for a newer version of this course  right away if it were to be released. Let's hope it happens. :-)

results.content:
Have done other wordpress theme development courses in the past but this one is a gem. Its the first course what actually walks out of the basic theme and covers really confusing topics. Actually I am surprised on how easy it is to follow. Also the guy has a very likeable voice and the pace is really comfortable. I was able to complete 1-2 hour long sessions without getting bored to death.. :)

The only note so far and I am at 60% is that I would like to have a section or at least 1 video on how to create custom fields without custom field plugin. The hard way..  Would be very helpful to know it especially if you dont want your client to mess around in admin panel and for example delete the plugin what will bring the whole site down.. To me this seems dangerous to rely solely on a plugin to power half of your custom code.

ISSUES: I have ran into issues what had to do with configuration of Virtual box and my gulp watch didn't work properly at the beginning however I got it all going eventually. 

I would suggest to use AMPPS for this course since its easy to create the .test domain without the need of manually editing the hosts file etc. Virtual box and vagrant is a bit confusing especially for any one who just starts in development. 

All in all this IMHO is one of the best wordpress courses. It really shows you the possibilities of this amazing software what go far beyond installing themes and building basic sites.

Regards,
Alex

results.content:
After i finished this course to be honest i learned a lot a lot of new stuff and a new way of thinking and programming in the same time, how ever i was expecting this course to cover more stuff like:
working with database directly edit and add (THIS WAS NEEDED TO BE INCLUDED)
how to implement plugins such as woocommerce , page builders(how to make page builder models ) and how can we overwrite some wordpress settings , for example making users upload images when sign up.
what i really liked about this course that now we have a perfect way to know how wordpress is working how wordpress rest api works and how to handle it , but in the same time there is some topic i really wanted the author to cover.

last thing i want to say for people who will take this course:
if you want to know a lot about wordpress features and how to create custom post types that course is for you , but if you want to know how to use plugins and you are expecting that you will be able to use any plugin in your website or know how to add any feature to your website that is not that course you are looking for.

thank you a lot brad for your time and this amazing course see you in next courses :)

results.content:
This course could easily be a 5-star for me but there's two drawbacks. Meantime, Brad's method is very engaging and clear, and this course introduces some nifty things one can bring to a WordPress website to sweeten its experience for users. However, I find Brad wanting in two areas: 1. poor to no reference to the Codex, docs, or function references in order to get learners familiar with the "factory" for when they'll have projects dissimilar to the one built in this course to work on; and 2. this course still didn't do it for me where an expert should do more stuff within the admin that a traditional theme developer would be doing, customizing meta boxes, adding admin columns, adding settings pages, etc. 

All in all, as engaging as this course is, I feel it grossly omits essential skills needed by a WordPress Developer. WordPress development courses need to be a lot more attuned to real-world usage and teach people how to address these both on the admin side and the front-end.

All in all, as engaging as this course is, I feel it grossly omits essential skills needed by a WordPress Developer. WordPress development courses need to be a lot more attuned to real-world usage and teach people how to address these both on the admin side and the front-end.

results.content:
This is one of the highest rated Udemy courses for PHP for wordpress development. I've noticed, however, that the ratings are only 2 or 3 stars recently, with the lack of instructor involvement and outdated material being the number 1 and 2 complaints, respectively. I now understand why. I got through 30%, was happy with it, but when certain things aren't working properly, no-one's questions are being answered. 
As an example, if a HUGE part of the course is built upon an existing wordpress plugin, but that plugin has been updated and works differently, this isn't reflected in the course, and it isn't addressed by the author. So I'm stuck at finishing about a third of the course, and can't go any further. I believe the course could now be considered outdated, and abandoned by Brad. You'll see the word "abandoned" throughout the newer reviews.

Great Course!! Very informative. Really glad I took the course!
Pros: Everything except ....
Cons: I wish he would spend some time talking about where you go for more information on a wordpress function (e.g. 'Go to codex.wordpress.org and search for function xxxx. Here it shows what arguments the function takes and a description of the purpose. It also shows different variations). He says that wordpress has a function called xxxx that takes 'x number' of arguments. I realize this would prolong the series but I think it's well worth it. Obviously, he can't do that all the time but at least have it be in the lecture from time to time. I think it promotes more independence on the students part.

results.content: The course material seems fairly dense for non-coders attempting to get a taste of WP development (IMO).  The pace is also (subjectively for me) pretty fast for the material being covered.  The last two lessons (10 & 11) in particular seem to pack a lot of detailed material into a very short amount of time.  It would be nice to vary the pace some and perhaps take a little longer when explaining concepts with fairly large implications for the final product appearance.  Concepts that are used consistently, such as calling functions from the library, might benefit with a bit more elaboration.  Are the functions that come built into WP organized, cataloged or indexed in some way that would allow for a more intuitive grasp of their naming conventions, applications or variations?  Being a newbie, I realize my opinion is likely of little value but those are some of the thoughts I've had up to this point in the course.  The presenter is obviously a subject matter expert and a skilled teacher as well.  The quality of the material seems first-rate based on past experiences with this kind of training.  Overall a very well designed course that covers many of the most practical tasks required to build a functional theme and interconnect disparate pieces together successfully.  I'm thoroughly enjoying the lessons and look forward to completing the course and putting what I've learned into practical application.  Thank You!

results.content:
Great course! Brad really goes in depth with WordPress and by the end of the course you really understand the fundamental concepts. I already new HTML/CSS and JavaScript and I when I bought this course I was hoping it would help give me an edge in finding a job. 

I've been job hunting for a week and a half and have been contacted by two companies I applied to specifically because of a WordPress website I made that directly incorporated the lessons I learned in this video. 

There are always more things to learn, more WordPress skills to acquire, and more knowledge to be gained, but if you're looking to 1) understand the core concepts of WordPress's backend system and 2) get a job, then this course is for you.

results.content:
A complete course, easy to understand with great explanation. After this course, you will be able to easily make your own project with user generated content. 

I did not have any problems with "all" the programs setup you need to get to follow Brad. I was using windows 10,wamp, git bash and gulp and i carefully followed his instructions, everything went fine. If you get stuck, you will probably read a lot of people in the Questions/Answers section complaining about their stuff doesn't work. 99% , it will be a typo, i assure you. YOU CAN'T GET STUCK following this course. 

The only section you need to think and use your brain a lil bit is the gulp section. Depending the hierarchy of your folder, you need to use logic to determine wich path/setup you need to follow in order to make the automation works. 

Simple Logic. 

Cheers,

If you have not done any PHP or Wordpress development, this is the course for you. If you have experience in PHP, but never done any Wordpress development - this is also the course for you.

If I will recommend this course? Absolutely! Without a doubt! Hands down!

results.content:
This is a very well made course. It moves at a good pace while still being fairly thorough. Yes, there are parts where things are glossed over and not really explained well, but they are minimal and necessary in order to keep the course to a reasonable length.

The biggest issue I had with the course was a lack of consistent skill-level expectations of the student. There were points when relatively simple things were overly explained. If you do not understand that topic at the given time then there is no way you're going to understand the rest of what is going on at that point in the course. While other things that were much more complicated were simply moved right through. Overall, excellent. That small issue was mildly frustrating on a few occasions is all.

results.content: I first took this course about two years ago and I dropped it soon after. Luckily I picked it up again this year and throughout the course, I've been patting myself on the back for the great decision of taking it on again. I feel the course really opened the door for me to becoming a developer that can make his own wp themes and plugins rather than remaining a consumer. With the help of the course, I can now go through wp theme codes and understand how they work and tweak them. The author is well-spoken and teaches in such a way that the work is easy to understand, I can not recommend this course enough to any developer interested in working with WordPress.
